articles.headline: Open-Armed Chicago Feels the Strains of a Migrant Influx
articles.snippet: Asylum seekers are pouring in at a fraught moment, when Chicago is changing mayors, its shelters are full, and a pandemic-driven restriction at the southern border is expected to end.
articles.abstract: Asylum seekers are pouring in at a fraught moment, when Chicago is changing mayors, its shelters are full, and a pandemic-driven restriction at the southern border is expected to end.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Bulging suitcases lined the wall of windows facing the street at a North Side police station in Chicago one morning this week. Air mattresses, blankets and pillows covered the shiny lobby floor. And more than 40 women, men and children were crowded together wherever they could find space — sleeping, chatting in Spanish or eating forkfuls of scrambled eggs and sausages that a volunteer had arranged on a long table.

articles.headline: Google Builds on Tech’s Latest Craze With Its Own A.I. Products
articles.snippet: At the company’s annual conference, Google demonstrated dozens of products and features that work with artificial intelligence, along with new phones.
articles.abstract: At the company’s annual conference, Google demonstrated dozens of products and features that work with artificial intelligence, along with new phones.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the San Francisco start-up OpenAI released ChatGPT late last year, the A.I. chatbot looked like the first significant threat in decades to Google. One day, tech insiders thought, it could make Google’s internet search engine look old and stodgy.

articles.headline: Pixel 7A Review: We’re Running Out of Reasons to Splurge on a ‘Pro’ Phone
articles.snippet: Google’s latest entry-level phone, which costs $500, is just as good as devices nearly double its price.
articles.abstract: Google’s latest entry-level phone, which costs $500, is just as good as devices nearly double its price.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not long ago, there were plenty of compelling reasons to spend upward of $900 on a smartphone. Nowadays, you’ll have to come up with an excuse to pay that much.

articles.headline: Disney’s Losses From Streaming Narrowed in the Last Quarter
articles.snippet: The company’s earnings were buoyed by its theme parks and cruise ships. It also announced it would soon put Hulu content on Disney+.
articles.abstract: The company’s earnings were buoyed by its theme parks and cruise ships. It also announced it would soon put Hulu content on Disney+.
articles.lead_paragraph: To understand the forces that have been roiling the biggest media companies, look no further than Disney’s earnings. Streaming economics are improving — considerably so. But not fast enough to offset declines in traditional television, which is in free fall.

articles.headline: How Past Debt Limit Crises Shaped Biden’s No-Negotiation Stance
articles.snippet: Battles in 2011 and 2013 taught President Biden not to lean on a House speaker who has little room to negotiate and to keep debt ceiling talks separate from the budget.
articles.abstract: Battles in 2011 and 2013 taught President Biden not to lean on a House speaker who has little room to negotiate and to keep debt ceiling talks separate from the budget.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a debt limit crisis loomed in 2011, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. described early negotiations with Republicans as civil, at one point suggesting that the process was about finding out who was willing to trade their side’s bicycle for the other side’s golf clubs.

articles.headline: New Defamation Suit Against Fox Signals Continued Legal Threat
articles.snippet: The suit, brought by a specialist in Russian disinformation, cites parallels with the recently settled Dominion Voting Systems case against Fox.
articles.abstract: The suit, brought by a specialist in Russian disinformation, cites parallels with the recently settled Dominion Voting Systems case against Fox.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fox News was hit on Wednesday with another defamation lawsuit, this one from a woman who said the network promoted lies about her that generated serious threats to her safety and harmed her career prospects.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: Taiwan Is Running Low on a Strategic Asset: Engineers
articles.snippet: Taiwan’s world-dominating microchip sector was built by TSMC’s skilled employees. But a demographic crisis, demanding work culture and flagging interest threaten its lead.
articles.abstract: Taiwan’s world-dominating microchip sector was built by TSMC’s skilled employees. But a demographic crisis, demanding work culture and flagging interest threaten its lead.
articles.lead_paragraph: Engineers like Royale Lee, 31, are one reason Taiwan is the world’s biggest contract producer of the microchips that power almost all electronics.
articles.byline: By John Liu and Paul Mozur

articles.headline: What’s Driving Record Levels of Migration to the U.S. Border?
articles.snippet: The United States is trying to curtail border crossings as a Covid-era immigration policy lifts this week, but it has little control over the crises in Latin America that have upended the lives of millions.
articles.abstract: The United States is trying to curtail border crossings as a Covid-era immigration policy lifts this week, but it has little control over the crises in Latin America that have upended the lives of millions.
articles.lead_paragraph: CIUDAD JUÁREZ, Mexico — Millions of people are leaving their homes across Latin America in numbers not seen in decades, many of them pressing toward the United States.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and Julie Turkewitz

articles.headline: ‘De-Americanize’: How China Is Remaking Its Chip Business
articles.snippet: Seven months after Washington unveiled tough curbs, Chinese companies are doubling down on homegrown supply chains and drawing billions in cash from Beijing and investors.
articles.abstract: Seven months after Washington unveiled tough curbs, Chinese companies are doubling down on homegrown supply chains and drawing billions in cash from Beijing and investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last October, construction plans for a hulking semiconductor factory owned by a major state-backed company in central China fell into disarray. The Biden administration had escalated the trade war over technology, severing China’s access to the Western tools and skilled workers it needed to build the most advanced semiconductors.
articles.byline: By Chang Che and John Liu

articles.headline: How Russia’s Rich Get Their Luxuries Now
articles.snippet: More than a year into Vladimir Putin’s invasion, the web of global trade has adjusted to Western sanctions, with a network of middlemen sending cars, electronics and more to Russia.
articles.abstract: More than a year into Vladimir Putin’s invasion, the web of global trade has adjusted to Western sanctions, with a network of middlemen sending cars, electronics and more to Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a dusty roadside on the outskirts of Dubai, Sohrab Fani is profiting from the West’s response to the war in Ukraine: his shop installs seat heaters into cars being re-exported to Russia.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: U.S. Focuses on Invigorating ‘Chiplets’ to Stay Cutting-Edge in Tech
articles.snippet: Chiplets, a way to design chips for higher performance, has become a key prong of U.S. industrial policy. But pushing for more of this activity domestically is challenging.
articles.abstract: Chiplets, a way to design chips for higher performance, has become a key prong of U.S. industrial policy. But pushing for more of this activity domestically is challenging.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than 50 years, designers of computer chips mainly used one tactic to boost performance: They shrank electronic components to pack more power onto each piece of silicon.

articles.headline: Bank of England Raises Interest Rates to Highest Level in 15 Years
articles.snippet: The central bank lifted its benchmark rate a quarter point, to 4.5 percent, as part of its aggressive policy to tame inflation, but forecast that Britain was likely to avoid a recession.
articles.abstract: The central bank lifted its benchmark rate a quarter point, to 4.5 percent, as part of its aggressive policy to tame inflation, but forecast that Britain was likely to avoid a recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Bank of England raised interest rates on Thursday, its 12th consecutive increase, as Britain’s inflation rate remained stubbornly in the double digits.

articles.headline: CNN Chairman Defends Decision to Host Trump Town Hall
articles.snippet: “People woke up, and they know what the stakes are in this election in a way that they didn’t the day before,” Chris Licht said in a morning call at the network.
articles.abstract: “People woke up, and they know what the stakes are in this election in a way that they didn’t the day before,” Chris Licht said in a morning call at the network.
articles.lead_paragraph: The chairman of CNN, Chris Licht, issued a robust defense on Thursday of his decision to broadcast a live town hall with former President Donald J. Trump, an unruly and at times bewildering event that has prompted criticism inside and outside of the network.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Benjamin Mullin
